Donna pulled out the menu and skimmed it. Something light. Something to tide her over for the next -- ugh -- eight hours. If she had this place for as long as she liked, she'd make sure she enjoyed it.

"Can I get...," she said, scanning the menu. Good lord, this laminated piece of paper had a scroll option. She flicked through the list and found something from Earth. "... a foot-long meatball sub with Parmesan and a sugar-free cola?"

"Nothing simpler," the waiter replied with a smile. He snapped his fingers.

A moment later, a flat piece of metal -- some sort of tray -- extended from the side of the lounger, and then a cup holder popped out from the other side. The sandwich materialized out of thin air on the tray, while the cup holder suddenly acquired a fizzy ice cold soda. Donna stared at them for a long moment before smiling weakly at the waiter. "Er... thanks."

"If you require anymore refreshment, just select the item you desire on the menu and snap your fingers. The telepathic synthesizer will do the rest." And with that, he turned and walked out, the door shutting behind him.

Donna groaned at the thought of being able to summon food just like that. She picked up the sub. Maybe it wouldn't be that good. But of course it was. It tasted delectable. Just like from her favorite sandwich shop on Earth. She took a sip of the soda and moaned at how good it tasted -- even without sugar. She let out a sad moan and continued to eat. She wondered if the TARDIS had planned this. She couldn't shaken the idea yet that the Doctor's time machine might be a chubby chaser constantly dumping her at places that would fatten her up. It'd be a helluva coincidence otherwise.

Soon, she had the whole foot long in her stomach, and she finished off the last of the soda. With a thick belch, she laid back in the lounger and enjoyed the warmth of the sun. She tried to ignore the fullness and how good it felt, focusing on the sun. She basked the lethal rays and tried to take another nap. However, she felt a teeny bit uncomfortable. She'd been wearing the robe for so long that she found her skin needed to breathe. She tried to ignore it, but after fidgeting awkwardly a few times, she finally yanked the robe open and slipped out of the sleeves, and now her naked form lay prone beneath the dome.

Donna took a moment to enjoy the warmth now spreading across her body as she took on the sun rays. She closed her eyes, trying not to care how she looked at the moment. She finally couldn't stop looking anymore and peered down at her body. Fairly large breasts, but then, she'd always been busty. Now, of course, her belly overtook them in the race to stick out the furthest. She gazed at the pale dome that rose and fell with every breath across her midsection. How it swelled, inflated, bulged... gurgled... Her meal continued to digest inside of her, making the most curiously cute bubbling sounds.

Looking around for any security cameras, Donna began to appreciate how alone she was. She gently placed her hands atop her gut and began to rub. It felt so firm yet soft -- jam-packed full of food and drink, with an extra-cushioned layer of flab encasing it. She rubbed it gently up and down, then gave it a few slaps, listening to the smacks reverberate through the big empty room.

"Bit on the plump side, aren't you," she murmured to her belly, slapping a light rhythm against it.

She could feel a small smile tugging at the side of her mouth. If only her mother could see her now. All the men who ever turned her down for being 'too big'. She jiggled and caressed her flab with increasing glee.

Then, she pulled out the menu, skimmed through it, selected an extra-large chocolate milkshake and snapped her fingers. It appeared in the cup holder beside her. Her heart racing, she chucked the straw and began to chug it eagerly. The size of the cup required the use of both hands, and she didn't even care as some of it dribbled down the sides of her face. She got at least ninety-five percent in her mouth.

On top of what she'd had before, she could feel herself getting fuller. Even before she reached the halfway point, she could feel herself getting far too stuffed to continue. She didn't care. She needed this. At least, she told herself she needed this. All those times her mother denied her sweets, all those times she felt ashamed for looking like herself, she needed to avenge those times and just wallow in some proper gluttony.

Soon, the cup clattered to the floor beside the lounger -- empty. Donna's stomach simply couldn't hold another drop. It heaved and churned noisily with its new load.

Donna's face, stained with chocolate, sported a dopey smile. She struggled into a sitting position and peered down at her belly's enormity.

"Well, look at you, Miss Noble," she murmured. "You've really piled it on now, haven't you? Proper pig, that's what you are, eh?" She grinned mischievously. "Ooooh, look at how found and fat you are, you naughty little piggy-wiggy!" She gently jiggled her belly, listening to the cargo shift inside. A tiny hiccup escaped, and she knew she had to hold still. Too much jiggling, and she'd be in real trouble.

Hands atop her belly, she fell asleep again.

When Donna awoke, she could tell it had been much longer this time. The sun had changed position, now a great deal lower than before. She lay in silence, staring up at it, for a few minutes. Then, out of the corner of her eye, she caught sight of a red light flashing on the lounger's arm. Dimly remembering being told the red light meant something urgent had happened, she pressed the intercom button.

"Yes?"

"Apologies for the interruption, Miss Noble," the voice on the other end said, "but I'm afraid something has happened. Your fellow traveler -- the Doctor? -- has been in some sort of emergency."

Donna felt some of that tension return to her shoulders. "What kind of 'emergency'?" she demanded.

"We're not sure, but it seems the shuttle bus he was traveling on was attacked by some sort of creature. Emergency shuttles have already brought him and the surviving passengers back to the leisure center. He's on his way to you now."

"Right... Yeah, thanks. I'll be here for him."

She immediately got her robe back on, all thoughts from earlier forgotten. Sod her weight and any concerns or pleasures that might come with it -- her friend needed her.

Not long after she got herself cleaned up, the door slid open, and the Doctor walked in. No stride, no energy, not even a twinkle in his eyes. In fact, his eyes had never looked more lifeless. Almost as if he'd been... broken.

Without missing a beat, Donna closed the distance between them and pulled him into the biggest hug ever. At first, he only halfheartedly returned it, but then, he wrapped both arms around her and squeezed her tightly, holding her as close as he could. She could almost feel the pain he'd been through just from being with him. She rubbed his back soothingly and waited for him to speak.

****

After nearly ten minutes, he finally began to talk. Telling the story of how the trip to the sapphire waterfalls had gone so horribly wrong, and how the creature had taken over a passenger, and how everyone had been suspicious of him, and how all his usual methods had been turned against him. And then, to have that thing in his head, stealing his voice, how it had almost manipulated them into killing him. Had it not been for the Hostess...

By the time they'd finished talking, he seemed a bit less dead inside, if only for getting it all off his chest. Before she knew it, the Doctor began informing the local authorities of the dangers out there. The creature could very well still be alive. There could even be more of them. Not the best place to build a leisure facility. Best to find some other place. After getting testimonials from the other passengers, they managed to ensure that Midnight Leisure would be shut down for good, saving anyone else from being endangered by the creature.

The pair returned to the TARDIS not long after. The Doctor hadn't quite gotten over his ordeal yet. He quietly set the controls and returned them to the vortex. He stood in silence for a long time, but Donna stood by him, not about to abandon him unless he said to. She sat on the jump seat and watched the time rotor rise and fall, her eyes occasionally flitting over to him. Sometimes it amazed her how much of his usual personality turned out to be bluster. Take away all that 'Doctor-y' stuff and, deep down, he's just a regular bloke.

After almost an hour of watching him, he finally seemed to come out of whatever thoughts he'd been lost in and started to move slowly around the console, making the odd adjustment and checking the readouts.

He didn't look up from the monitor when he spoke. "Have I ever told you how brilliant you are?"

Donna snorted, as if by instinct. "Pfft! Am not."

"No, you are," he said quietly, finally looking at her. "I think you're something I've always needed. I've always needed a friend like you." He began to walk again. "Sometimes, I think I only bring people along just so I have someone to be impressed by me. People who make me feel wonderful through their adoration as they lead them through death and carnage... And then, there's you, and you just utterly refuse to be impressed by me."

Donna blinked, bemused. "Well, sorry..."

"No, that's my point! You're the friend I need more than ever, because you don't see me as this unstoppable force of charisma and heroism and brilliant cleverness..."

"Only cuz you're not."

"You see me as... a person. I mean, Rose, she just always seemed to have stars in her eyes, and Martha, well, you've met her -- I think I stamped those stars out a little too well... But then you come along and call me a 'big long streak of alien nothing'..." He began to smile. "You're the best friend I've always needed."

Donna felt her heart begin to swell. Not just from the relief that this hadn't ended with an undying declaration of love, but from the eloquence and the thought he'd clearly put into that speech. Had he just spent the last hour mentally practicing that? Damn it, why couldn't he be husband material? So unfair. The only truly decent bloke she'd ever meet, and he's a damn alien with two hearts and doesn't make her heart pound in any way, except when they're running from something.

Unable to come up with the words, she got up from the seat and pulled him into another hug. He returned it and held her close.

"So you're gonna all right?" she asked. "It's okay for you to not be all right."

"I'll be all right," he assured her. "Been through so much worse... I just... after what happened, I didn't want to miss the chance to say all that again."

Donna smiled. "Well, I'm always here whenever you want to heap on the praise," she replied, allowing herself a small moment of pride.

He chuckled and let her go. "All right," he said, straightening his tie as if shouldering himself back together. "What do you fancy now?"

"Change of clothes, for a start," Donna chuckled. "Been in this robe for too long. After that... I dunno. Maybe skip the fancy leisure worlds and find something simple?"

The Doctor grinned. "I think I can just about manage 'simple'."

Donna shook her head and turned to leave, only to almost trip over something. She looked down and groaned. "And why is your weird severed-hand-in-a-jar always sitting out?"

The Doctor blinked, then peered down at the hand in question. "I dunno...," he murmured. "Just... felt like it should be there."

"Right, because nothing finishes off a room like a severed hand in a bubbling jar."

He seemed to consider this for a moment before shrugging. He got a hook from the console and used it to haul up one of the steel meshes that made up the floor, finding a storage cupboard underneath. He took the jar and gently slipped it inside. "There we are. Out of sight, out of mind," he beamed.

Donna rolled her eyes but smiled gratefully before heading for the wardrobe -- a journey she'd been dreading.

Donna made it back to the wardrobe room, peering through the clutter and seeking out some clothes. She dug through everything, trying to get her hands on something comfortable. If they really could get to a relaxing place, she needed something she wouldn't be squeezed into. Something that would give her room to breathe.

Certainly a lot of clothes in here -- although most of them were far too small. She guessed that a lot of them belonged to the Doctor's past companions. Did he never travel with anyone plus-sized? Rolling her eyes, she dug out some more clothes, trying to find something that would fit. Infinite storage space -- there had to be something. If not, she'd have to take the Doctor on a shopping trip, and she couldn't bear the thought of trying to take him shopping. He'd be like a kid -- bored out of his skull and more interested in the toy section and begging for a sweet. Last thing she needed right now were sweets.

Then, as she came out of another cove of clothes, her eyes fell on something familiar -- her fat jeans. Those trousers had always been her trousers of last resort. Never went anywhere in those unless she had no choice. Grimacing to herself, she went over and began to slip them on under the robe. She got them up to her waist and began to fasten them. Except, she didn't quite, because they wouldn't fasten. There was just too much belly for them to simply button up.

"Oh god, no," she moaned sadly.

Unable to see, she slipped the robe off and dropped it on the floor. Now completely topless, she set to work trying to do them up. She sucked in her gut and tried to squeeze them on. The gap shrank, but not quite enough. She took a deep breath and tried to suck it in even more, but it didn't make much difference. She pulled and pulled, but nothing happened. She tripped over the robe and landed on her back in a pile of clothes. Barely noticing, she tried again. Suck in gut, lie on back, fasten the button. Just as simple as one... two... three!

The button slipped through the hole and held. She did up the zip. She lay there on her back, feeling smothered by these damn jeans.

Who designed jeans, anyway? she wondered. Sadists?

She tried sitting up, but they squeezed her middle so hard that sitting up straight proved an even bigger challenge than getting the damn things on. She thrashed briefly, hoping to get onto her feet, but the jeans proved too painful for that sort of luxury. She rolled this way and that, trying to get herself upright. She shrieked in fury as the jeans simply refused to let her move.

At last, she managed it. She rolled herself backwards, and the opposite momentum catapulted her upright. She sat on her considerable rump and realized her success, letting out a triumphant "Woo-hoo!"

The button promptly gave. It shot across the room, vanishing into another pile of clothes. Her belly surged forward, absolutely relieved to breathe and stretch out.

Donna let out a yelp, then stared after the missing button. Her hands rested atop her belly, which she peered down at and positively marveled at how far out it protruded beyond the jeans.

Then, a curious thing happened. She began to laugh. Slowly at first, then a bit louder. She covered her mouth, not sure what was so damn funny, but she supposed it had to do with all the years of worrying about her size, and yet, here she was, finally the biggest she'd ever been, and arguably happier than she'd ever been.

She patted her stomach delightedly and walked around, still in these super-tight jeans, her belly jiggling freely. She found a button-down shirt that clearly didn't belong on someone her size. She promptly slipped it on and held in her stomach as she buttoned it up. Then, standing in front of a full-length mirror, she let out that breath. Her stomach expanded to its true size, and all the buttons went flying. She let out another gasp and laughed again.

She pulled out a black vest and repeated the process. Suck in gut, button up, breathe out, buttons fly. Her belly dominated every button she put over it. She laughed like a lunatic and continued the process, finding shirts, vests, skirts, trousers -- and her belly utterly destroyed all of them. Buttons flew, seams ripped, zippers burst -- she didn't know why this was so much fun, but she suspected it to be something cathartic.

After a good twenty minutes of this, though, the novelty began to wear off. Tired but still giddy, she plodded naked among the sea of ruined clothes and finally came across a much more size appropriate pair of slacks. She slipped them on and buttoned them up, smiling at the way the button easily fastened.

"Well, I'm sure I'll get around to ruining these one day," she muttered, giving her belly one more pat.

She pulled out a light sweater and a long coat to go over them before turning and heading back for the control room.

Donna made it back to the control room and took it in. The Doctor continued to work at the console, briefly looking up when she came in.

"Right!" he said. "Let's see if I got this right... Simple! Relaxing! No monsters or aliens or rips in space and time! Just simple relaxation!"

Glad to see that he'd started to cheer up, she walked all the way in. "So where is that?"

The Doctor grinned and pulled the main lever. They came in for their usual bumpy landing and clutched the railings as the ship settled. He led her down the ramp and opened the doors to a picturesque autumn afternoon. Green grass, orange leaves fluttering around, a river with ducks quacking, and people walking around, laughing, chatting, eating...

Donna saw the amount of snacking going on -- hotdogs, hamburgers, ice creams, drinks -- and saw that some sort of festivity taking place up along the sidewalk.

"Where are we?" she asked.

"United States," he said, "but I aimed for one of the nicer bits. Nothing fancy -- just gravitated towards a fun evening. This is a little festival this lot have every year. Lots of places to walk, talk, feed ducks, feed fish, feed yourself..."

Donna bit her lip. It all looked delicious, and the concession stands seemed to go for miles along the river. "I don't have any money."

"Ah. Hang on." He reached into his pocket and pulled out a plastic payment card. "There. I've got a bank account somewhere. Go mad."

Her mouth fell open as she took it. "And you're just now telling me about this because...?"

"With great power comes great responsibility." Off her look, he added, "And I lost it until last week."

She smirked as she took his arm. "That sounds like you."

They set off into the lovely day ahead of them. As they got further out into this new location, Donna marveled at the catfish that swam just below the surface. The Doctor, naturally, went into a long story about the time he and his friend Peri once saved a race of alien catfish from something called the Goronite, but she zoned in and out of the story. The place was simply too gorgeous to listen. She enjoyed looking around the scenery, listening to music and people talking. Little kids trying to feed the ducks, and their parents having to fish them out of the river afterwards. All the sorts of things she missed.

Of course, she wouldn't let such a veritable feast go to waste. So many food stalls, so little time.

She ate a cheeseburger while the Doctor made conversation with some ducks. She ate a bag of chips while wading in the shallow water. She drank at least five cans of pop while watching people ice skate in a small rink -- while the Doctor showed off his moves, of course. She ate three hotdogs while they walked the length of the river to see where it all went. She ate two ice cream cones while they watched the sunset over the town. She ate a bag of popcorn while they enjoyed a colored-light show set to music in the town square. She ate another cheeseburger, along with pop and chips, while they sat on a hill and admired the stars.

The Doctor had gone quiet some time ago, just taking in the world around him, admiring the fun in that way aliens always seemed to find so curious about humans. Donna finished off her burger and washed it all down with one last drink of soda, before lying back, hands atop her stomach. She simply couldn't eat another bite. Her stomach had that jam-packed feeling she'd enjoyed on Midnight, and the once comfortable slacks now felt tight around her middle. She smiled as she took in the view around her. So many people, so much fun to be had, and all of it to be had with her best mate.

"I need more days like this," she murmured.

"Yeah, it's good, this," the Doctor agreed. "Still, have too much fun, it gets a bit dull."

"Well, we're not all adrenaline junkies like you."

"Oi, I'll have you know I don't go looking for trouble."

"No, but you have to answer every distress call. Even the ones that turn out to be nothing."

"This isn't about the Moonites again, is it? Because there is such a thing -- just not on that particular moon..."

Donna rolled her eyes but felt too stuffed and bloated to argue. "Phew," she sighed, lying flat on her back. "I'm exhausted. I could just lie here all night."

"We can try," he said, lying down with her. "Of course, that's up to the park security."

"Let them try to move me. I'll show 'em I'm secure enough."

The Doctor chuckled. "Not touching that one."

Donna gave him a mock-annoyed look before leaning back and gazing up at the sky, listening to the lovely digestive soundtrack her stomach provided.

The next week was largely spent in the TARDIS. Aside from the odd stop off to look at alien worlds, the Doctor and Donna spent some downtime together. Of course, the time ship had plenty to offer in ways of entertainment. They watched some future television series, particularly enjoying a miniseries called Good Omens -- the Doctor insisted he had nothing to do with production and that snake contacts only made his eyes itch -- and also the 2030 reboot of Last of the Summer Wine -- somehow including every character from the old version in every episode.

Donna appreciated the downtime, and she suspected the Doctor did, too. She tried not to eat too during this time. She made use of the library to reread some of her favorites, and she'd done a few laps in the swimming pool in the interest of getting at least some exercise. She didn't know why they felt the need to go somewhere fancy like Midnight -- the TARDIS often seemed like a futuristic leisure center.

Of course, it also had a gym with workout equipment, but for some reason, Donna just couldn't bring herself to use it.

Then, one day, the Doctor announced he'd found another planet that would give them some fun.

"Shan Shen!" he announced. "Brilliant place! Been here a couple of times..."

"Been here with Martha?" she asked.

"Oh, long before Martha. Lifetimes. I was a different man back then."

Donna frowned briefly but let it go. "So what's it like, this Shan Shen?"

The Doctor threw the lever, and they felt the TARDIS land. "See for yourself!"

Donna gasped when she looked outside. They'd landed in an alleyway decorated with flags and pagodas, with lots of Chinese-style writing on them. People -- possibly human -- milled around in what appeared to be some kind of celebration.

"Oh, brilliant!" she exulted. "This place is amazing!"

"That it is!" the Doctor said as they stepped outside, pulling the door shut behind him. "Shan Shen -- land of opportunity!" He frowned briefly. "And okay, yes, an old enemy said that as a way of tricking me out of my exile on Earth, but whatever -- it's still true!"

They walked into the crowd and admired all the stalls and fun. Wooden stalls, crates, barrels, cages of...

"Are those real chickens?!" Donna asked.

"Y'know, I believe they are."

Donna looked up at the sky, which looked fairly blue except for all the other planets she could clearly see. "So are these people human?"

"Most of them, yes. Shan Shen is largely a trading post, but we've landed during one of their many celebrations. Always something to celebrate on Shan Shen!"

Donna greatly enjoyed this place. They chatted with a few stallholders, who had loads of stories to tell about their products. Some sold clothing, some sold knickknacks, some sold animals... and, of course, some sold food.

Naturally, Donna eagerly sampled plenty of the local cuisine. She tried to limit herself to small portions, but a little could go a long way. Certain meats and cheeses, plenty of exotic fruits, and some frothy sugary drink that left her with a foam mustache -- so many different flavors, and all of them delicious.

At some point, she noticed the Doctor had become enraptured with some sea urchins at another stall. Smiling fondly at his enthusiasm, she left him to it and looked around, hoping to maybe find another snack.

"Tell your fortune, lady?"

Donna turned and saw a young dark-skinned woman standing in a doorway, giving her an intriguing look.

"The future predicted. Your life foretold," she continued with all the charm of a used car salesman.

"No, thanks," Donna replied politely.

"Don't you want to know? If you're going to be happy?"

Donna continued to force a polite smile. "I'm happy right now, thank you."

"You've got red hair. The reading's free, for red hair."

God, this woman was relentless. But Donna felt suspicious. If she didn't want money...

"Yeah, all right, then," she said.

She followed the woman through the doorway, and found herself in a dark room, shrouded with drapes; incense in the air; the walls just broken concrete, like this downtown society had built itself into abandoned warehouses and tenements.

They sat across from each other at a small table. The Fortune Teller took Donna's hands and breathed in deep.

"Ohhh you're fascinating," she breathed. "No, but you're good. I can see... a man. The most remarkable man. How did you meet him?"

Donna raised an eyebrow. "You're supposed to tell me."

"I see the future. Tell me the past. When did your lives cross?"

"It's kind of complicated. I ended up in his spaceship on my wedding day. Long story."

Somewhere behind her, she thought she heard a quiet noise -- somewhere near the floor -- that went hissss-tic-tic-tic, but she dismissed it as coming from the marketplace outside.

The Fortune Teller continued. "But what led you to that meeting?"

Donna thought back. "Well. All sorts of things, but... My job, I suppose. It was on Earth, this planet called Earth. Miles away. But I had this job, as a temp, I was a secretary, in a place called H.C. Clements - "

Suddenly, images of her working at H.C. Clements slammed into her mind, causing her to reel briefly from the mental impact.

"Whoa... Sorry," she breathed.

The Fortune Teller smiled. "It's the incense. Betters the memory. Just breathe deep."

The scuttling noise behind her sounded a bit closer now.

"D'you ever think...?" the Fortune Teller asked, regaining her attention. "What if you'd never met this man? If your life had taken a different path?"

"Yeah. I got lucky."

"But was there ever a choice? This job of yours. What choices led you there?"

"There was a choice. Six months before. Cos the agency offered me a contract at H.C. Clements... but there was this other job, my mother knew this man..."

She felt the flashbacks of her mother telling her about another job at a different place, with better money and opportunities...

"Your life could have gone one way, or the other. What made you decide?"

"... I just did..."

"But when was the moment, the precise moment? When did you choose??"

Donna's mind filled with images -- the car, her mother nagging her, turn left or right... She'd turned left.

"You turned left. But what if you'd turned right? What then?"

Even the incense couldn't disguise the fact that this meeting was going very wrong. Donna tried to wrench herself free, but the Fortune Teller held tight. The hissing and ticking behind her got louder.

"What if it changes? What if you go right? What if you could still go right?"

Whatever hissed and ticked seemed to be right in her ear now as something landed on her back.

"What's that?! What's on my back? What is it? What's on my back??"

"Make the choice again, Donna Noble, and change your mind, turn right! Turn right! Turn right!"

Donna felt that choice before her all over again... and the world changed around her.

13531122222211121121122.content:
"Bad Wolf."

The words echoed in Donna's mind as she came out of it. They faded into the background as a loud hissing and clicking made her look back and spot the large Time Beetle that kicked and screeched as it died. "What the hell is that?!" she demanded.

The Fortune Teller cowered in a corner at the sight of her. "You were so strong...," she whimpered. "What are you? What will you be?!" She scuttled off into the darkness.

Moments later, the Doctor arrived and, upon seeing the beetle, explained it belonged to something called 'the Trickster's Brigade'. Apparently, it had reached back along her timeline and changed her personal history, creating a parallel world around her, and but she'd been strong enough to fight and changed things back. Donna, however, couldn't shake something as she tried to remember that world -- a blonde woman telling her that the "darkness" was coming, and those two words:

"Bad Wolf... What does it mean?"

Apparently, the blonde woman was Rose Tyler, and 'Bad Wolf' meant the end of the universe, so the Doctor and Donna fled Shan Shen and went to check on the Earth, only to find everything the same as they'd left it. However, when they popped back inside, the planet disappeared. With little choice if they wanted to find it again, they headed for the Shadow Proclamation; basically a sort of space police. After a chat with some albino women and talking rhinos with guns, they found that twenty-four planets had disappeared in total, and then, they realized three more from different times. With twenty-seven planets, it seemed they would be used for some kind of engine.

Thankfully, when Donna made mention that the bees were disappearing, the Doctor realized they could use the Taconda Scale to follow the planets. They followed the trail in the TARDIS, only to find that it ended at the Medusa Cascade. For a moment, it seemed hopeless they would ever find the planets, but then, Martha's cellphone started ringing. Instead of her voice, they heard a signal being transmitted. Straight away, they managed to get inside the Cascade -- it was a second out of sync with the rest of the universe, making it the perfect hiding place -- and got in touch with their callers: Captain Jack Harkness, Martha Jones and Sarah Jane Smith, who reported that the Daleks -- whoever they were -- had taken the planets for some reason.

The screen filled with static, and a sinister voice that apparently knew the Doctor spoke. The feed switched to an emaciated man with a glowing robot eye and in a futuristic wheelchair thing covered in silver bumps. This man, Davros, had created the Daleks from cells of his own body, and he had been saved from the Time War by something called Dalek Caan -- a weird-looking squid-like thing that cackled and flailed inside a destroyed Dalek casing. The Doctor, however, cut the call short and set the TARDIS in motion for Earth. They would find his friends and set to work on beating them. Donna knew he would.

They landed in a deserted London street. Stepping into the night air, they stared at the empty streets, cars and litter scattered everywhere.

"It's like a ghost town," Donna murmured.

"Sarah Jane said they were taking the people," said the Doctor. He rounded on her. "Think, Donna! When you met Rose in that parallel world, what did she say to you?"

"Just 'the darkness is coming'."

"Anything else?"

Donna started to reply, but then, she saw a familiar blonde at the far end of the street. "Why don't you ask her yourself?" she asked with a smile.

He looked confused for a moment, but then, he followed her eye-line and spotted her. For a moment, he didn't do anything. Then, he began to run. From the other end, Rose began to run as well.

Donna watched on with a smile. Perhaps due to all those soppy romance novels she read, she loved a star-crossed reunion like this.

Then, when they were almost to each other, a voice rang out, "EXTERMINATE!"

A blue bolt of laser shot through the air, and it glanced the Doctor's side, lighting up his body in a sad blue flare. He fell to the ground.

With a gasp of horror, Donna began running. It proved difficult, but even with her extra heft, she wasn't about to let it slow her down now. She saw another bolt of laser from the opposite direction, but this one was white and fired by that Captain Jack bloke. The Dalek exploded in flame.

By the time she got there, Rose was already cradling the Doctor and begging him not to die.

"Get him back to the TARDIS! Quick!" Captain Jack ordered.

Rose and Donna hoisted the shivering Doctor up and half-dragged him back to the TARDIS. Jack covered them with both his and Rose's guns.

Once back inside, they unloaded him on the floor. Donna's panic began to take control of her mouth. "What do we do?!" she nearly wept. "There must be some medicine or something!"

"Just step back," said Jack calmly. He looked to Rose. "Rose -- do as I say and get back! He's dying, and you know what happens next!"

"No!" Rose wailed. "I came all this way...!"

Donna, however, felt a grain of hope in Jack's words. "Whatcha mean? What happens next?!"

The Doctor grunted in pain on the floor, and then he held his hand up. To Donna's shock, it began to glow with golden energy. "It's starting!" he gasped.

Jack grabbed Rose and dragged her to safety on the other side of the console. "Here we go! Good luck, Doctor!"

"Will someone please tell me what is going on?!" Donna demanded, shouting at the world because no one was listening.

Rose managed to regain some composure. "When he's dying," she choked, "his body... it repairs itself. It changes." She broke again. "But you can't!"

The Doctor regarded her sadly. "I'm sorry. It's too late," he struggled to say, as if holding something back. "I'm regenerating!"

135311222222111211211221.content:
For a brief moment, the Doctor's body convulsed, and his face and hands lit up with golden energy, but he managed to hold it back again, wincing in pain.

"What's happening to you?" Donna asked, stunned.

"Regenerating. I'm dying, so my whole body is changing. I'm just... ugh... holding it back to..." His head dropped briefly.

"To what?!"

He managed to raise his head again. "... to say good bye," he finished with a sad smile. "Just... things I wanted to say... while I still have this voice..."

Donna could feel the tears coming. "But... you're gonna be okay, right?" she whimpered. "I mean, even if you change, you'll still be you, right?"

He tapped his forehead. "I will be in here, where it counts. Just trust me, all right? Don't give up on me. Because I've changed. Promise?"

Donna nodded, still crying. "I won't," she replied, her voice thick with sorrow. "I promise."

The Doctor smiled, the energy slowly burning creeping up his face again. "Right then," he said, stepping away from them. "For real this time." He took a deep breath, flashed a determined smile and let the fire take him. "Allons-y!"

His face and hands lit up in volcanic bursts of gold, causing her to bury her face in Jack's chest. She tried to watch, but it was far too bright. It seemed to on for ages, but soon, the light faded away, and a moment later, she could see again. She blinked before looking over at the Doctor. He stood with her back to them, but right away, she could see how different he'd become. Taller, nowhere near as skinny, crazy strawberry blonde hair -- a whole new man.

The new Doctor made a face as if he were chewing something he didn't like.

"New voice," he said at last. "Tastes weird..."

His legs gave out, and he went crashing to the metal floor, landing in an unconscious heap. Donna ran to his side in an instant, followed by Jack. He began checking him all over.

"Is he all right?!" she asked urgently.

Jack checked the Doctor's pulse. "Hearts are still beating. Thing about regeneration is -- it can shake up the brain cells a little. Might cause temporary amnesia, mood swings, light coma..."

"But it's him, isn't it? I mean, he is the Doctor, right?"

He put a hand on her shoulder to reassure her. "Yes, Donna, I promise -- he is the Doctor. Tell her, Rose." At the blonde woman's silence, he looked up. "Rose?"

But Rose just looked catatonic, staring straight ahead with no emotion in her eyes, her tear-streaked face absolutely blank.

Jack got up and gently shook her shoulders. "Rose, I'm sorry, but we need your head in the game. I know it hurts, but he's still here. Right in front of you. And he needs us right now."

Rose closed her eyes, squeezing out a few more tears, but she nodded and walked over to join Donna by the Doctor. Gently, they rolled him over so he was flat on his back, and they took in his new face. A bit younger, although not much. Fresh face, some freckles, bushier sideburns, very pale -- and the suit really didn't fit anymore.

"Doctor...?" Rose ventured. "Doctor, it's me. I'm here. Please, wake up. We need you."

No response.

Rose looked like she would start to cry again, but she also looked a little angry. "Doctor, please. Daleks are invading. People are dying. We need you right now." She paused. "I need you."

Still nothing.

Donna didn't like just doing nothing, so she leaned in closer as well. "Doctor, come on, you great big dumbo. You're not about to let those ugly tin cans win, are you?"

For a moment, nothing. Then... the Doctor's face screwed up in a wince as he put a hand to his forehead.

"Doctor, are you all right?" Rose asked urgently.

"... I'm fine, thank you, Susan," he replied, eyes still not open yet.

Rose looked mildly put out, but Jack quickly reassured her. "Like I said. Brain's a bit shaken up. Give him time. He'll be all right."

"Quite right, Jamie," the Doctor said, rubbing his face. "Just need a moment to gather my thoughts."

Then, he lowered his eyes and looked right at Donna. She saw that his eyes had changed from dark brown to a sort of bluish-green. He looked at her with a foreboding brow, as if absorbing every last thing about her.

"Are you okay?" she asked warily.

The Doctor stared a moment longer, and then he smiled. "Much better now, Donna. Thank you," he said, unaware that Rose looked indignant behind him. "How are you?"

Donna squinted her eyes suspiciously at him. "You're really the Doctor?" she asked. "Prove it."

He thought for a moment, and then he smiled again. "One day -- one of the saddest days of my life -- I thought I would never be happy again. But then, I looked up, and there was this woman in my TARDIS, wearing a wedding dress. She turned around, and the first thing she said to me was..." He made a high-pitched indignant squeak. "And then, in return, I said, 'What?!'"

"Oh my god, it is you," Donna breathed.

"Hello!"

SLAP!

Rose and Jack winced as her hand collided with his face, making him stagger back in surprise.

"What was that for?!"

"For not telling me you could just change bodies like that! That's important to know, you dunce!"

"Well, I'm sorry, but it's not an easy thing to talk about! Ugh -- that was a brand new cheek you've just slapped, and now it's gonna go all red!" Then, his eyes widened. "Ooh, red! That reminds me! Very important! Matter of life and death!" He took a very serious tone. "Am I... ginger?"

Donna stared, then glanced at his hair. "... Sort of?"

"What do you mean, 'sort of'?"

"Well, it's sort of... blondish-red. Sort of... strawberry blonde."

He considered this for a moment, then began to smile. "Well! That's all right then! Probably because of you and... her...," he said, gesturing vaguely to Rose, who looked rather put out again. "Blonde and ginger together -- rubs off!"

"What, and you got your accent from Captain Jack?" she smirked.

He frowned. "Accent? Have I got an accent? Doesn't sound -- ohhhhh I hear it now! American! I've gone American!" He looked a bit nauseous now. "Ugh, does this mean I'm going to become all condescending and entitled?"

Donna began to laugh, and then he began to laugh, too. Then, she noticed Rose and Jack had been standing off to the side, looking a little left out, so she gently turned him around to face them. "Er, Doctor?"

The Doctor calmed his giggling and seemed to notice the other two for the first time. "Ah! Yes! Hello!" He looked intensely at Jack. "Haven't we met somewhere before? ...Julius Caesar...? No, too tall... Newton? No..." Then he smiled -- he had it. "Oh yes! Captain Jack Harkness! How are you?" he asked, immediately shaking the other man's hand.

"Fine, thanks," Jack replied, beginning to smile.

The Doctor noticed Rose. "And Rose Tyler! Welcome back! Good to see you again!" Then, without even really waiting for a response, he looked to Jack again, perplexed. "Now then... what was I doing?"

At that moment, the lights went down, plunging them into darkness.

"Oh yes," he said in the gloom. "Daleks."

1353112222221112112112212.content:
Donna scolded herself for constantly glancing, but she couldn’t help herself. He was just so… different!

The Doctor stood at the controls, leaning against the console and looking lost in thought. It had been thirty-six minutes since they’d left Bad Wolf Bay - a decidedly bittersweet affair.

It all could’ve been much worse, she kept telling herself. The universe nearly ended. Major not good averted. Everyone on the team survived. Sarah Jane returned to her son, Captain Jack to Torchwood, and Martha and Mickey… to do whatever they were going to do. She recalled the smile on the Doctor’s face as he’d bid them farewell, hugs and all. She smirked as she remembered Sarah Jane’s admonishment.

“Don’t go changing again before next time! It’s getting difficult to keep up!”

She wondered whether Rose rejected him because of that. Those changes, they took getting used to. Donna still kept glancing, waiting to see if it turned out that an imposter now roamed the TARDIS and she found her Doctor locked in a cupboard somewhere. She listened for any knocks on the walls, but nothing. Anyway, he seemed to know what he was doing, so she left him to it.

Sarah Jane’s words of reassurance gave her comfort. “Sometimes, you look at him, and you can’t believe it’s the same man. You feel like you lost someone. But then, after a while, you realize, you didn’t lose anyone. You’ve just met the same person a second time. Or, in my case, a third or fourth, but the point still stands.”

She remembered Jack’s assurances as the new Doctor struggled to walk in his now-super-tight suit. She remembered Mickey laughing that he’d ‘gone and done it again’. She remembered Jackie asking him if he wanted a cup of tea to ‘help the ions or whatever’.

She also remembered Rose’s heartbreak. Rose’s silence. Rose’s coldness. Oh, she got on with saving the universe, fine, but she hadn’t said a word to him once they boarded the TARDIS to tow the Earth home.

Martha gave him a brief physical on the way home, but she overall took the change in her stride. Apparently, she met another Time Lord (not so dead after all, eh, Spaceman) and witnessed him regenerate, so she at least knew about it.

“It’s one thing to know about it, but it’s another thing to live through it. Still, it’s not so bad. Sometimes, I look into his eyes, and I think I can see him.”

Donna couldn’t see his eyes right now. The Doctor disappeared under the console to work on it. Just a distraction to get his mind off it.

Once on the beach, Jackie gave Donna a hug and said goodbye, then hugged the Doctor, who smiled sheepishly and apologized for never having dinner with her. Old joke, probably. Rose, however, said goodbye to them, took one last look around the TARDIS, then turned and left.

Donna glanced across at the Doctor before he snapped his fingers and shut the doors, pulling the lever that took them back into the vortex.

Definitely a day for surprises. The surprise from the Supreme Dalek when the Doctor stepped out of the TARDIS with Rose and Donna, wearing a new face. The surprise from Davros when the TARDIS materialized safe and sound in the Vault, piloted by Captain Jack, who immediately kept him at bay while Sarah Jane and Mickey freed them. Surprise from Martha when she found she wouldn’t need the Osterhagen Key after all.

Even Dalek Caan expressed surprise at how his prophecies got away from him, but he simply giggled madly and expressed joy that “death has been averted”, whatever that meant.

Despite all the fun they had destroying the Reality Bomb and pushing the Daleks around, the light never really entered Rose’s eyes again. Donna attempted to talk to her during the flight home, but it wasn’t until they were en route to the parallel world that she explained.

“My Doctor is dead. I know it’s supposed to be the same man, but it’s really not. No matter what he says, he’s so… different… He’s not my Doctor. He’s literally not the man I fell in love with.”

Donna looked over at the Doctor. Huge feet sticking out of the console, working on the wiring or something, he remained quiet. So unnatural. Used to be when he was upset, he raced around the control room, trying to outrun his sadness.

The silence unnerved her.

She got up from the jumpseat and sat cross legged next to him on the grated floor.

“Hey,” she said quietly.

He poked his head out briefly before resuming his work. “Hey,” he replied.

“You all right?”

“... No.”

Donna nodded. Not even trying to hide it. Something she could work with.

“Whatcha working on?”

“Zyton Crystals. Seems they got a bit fried towing Earth.”

Donna gently placed a hand on his leg, and he stopped working. He didn’t look up, but he stopped working.

“It’s not your fault.”

“I know.”

“She just doesn’t understand.”

“I know. It’s just… everybody else did. Why didn’t she?”

Donna gently tugged on his plaid button-down shirt - which she’s totally going to make him change out of later - and made him sit up and look at her.

“If she can’t accept it, then she was never really in love with you anyway,” she said sadly. “She just… wasn’t the right one for you.”

A moment later, he looked up, but the eyes looked less sad, and the boyish twinkle returned. She really could see him there.

He slammed shut the console and got to his feet, groaning as he did. “Oooof, I tell ya. This metal grating makes a lousy floor… You know, I think it’s time I made some changes around here...”

“Oh goody, more changes,” she sighed. “Gonna get a proper sofa in here?”

“No, I was thinking of replacing the metal, the grime, the coral and maybe getting something with wood paneling. Maybe a smaller console. Might make flying it less hectic. Save energy for running from monsters…”

Donna looked around the giant control room with dread. She didn’t like the idea of DIY-ing the TARDIS, but whatever got him up and running again. “Well, you know what we need if we’re going to rebuild?” She smiled. “Doughnuts.”

His eyebrows rose in surprise. “Doughnuts?”

“Oh God, yes, and fresh ones. I’m so famished, I could eat a dozen chocolate iced with sprinkles. Can we find a doughnut shop somewhere?”

The Doctor stared at her, and then he laughed, heading for the controls, nabbing his new wide-brimmed fedora off the stand and wrapping his scarf around his neck. “Come on then, Miss Noble! I know an excellent doughnut joint on Bandraginous Five! More rainbow sprinkles than you can stick a shake at!”

“Shake a stick at,” she corrected.

“Why would I want to shake a stick? Come on!”

Donna smiled. This seemed like the re-starting of a beautiful friendship.

13531122222211121121122121.content:
Donna stepped out of the TARDIS and took in Bandraginus Five. Purple sky, with the celestial system of many nearby planets -- presumably Bandraginuses One thru Four, and maybe a Six -- with the odd shuttlecraft zooming overhead. People with rough humanoid shapes -- save for the extra limb or two.

The Doctor stepped out behind her, locking the door as he did. "Ahhh, just as I remember it!" he said cheerfully. "Unless we've arrived before last time. In which case, it's just as I'm going to experience it later!"

Donna rolled her eyes. "Yeah, it's great," she said. "When is this?"

He stuck his tongue out as if licking the air. "Tastes like 6043," he said at last. "Fairly quiet time in the planet's history." He gave the air another taste. "Possible chances of rain in the afternoon."

Donna looked at him for a long moment. "You can actually taste the air and know what year it is?"

"Sometimes. Depends on the tongue. Clearly, this one has a more refined palette than the old one." Then, his eyes lit up. "Oooh! Doughnut shop! That way!"

He hooked her arm and led her towards a small building that stood alone on the street and took her through the door. Donna felt annoyed -- he had longer legs now and keeping up with his pace felt exhausting.

Still, arriving in the doughnut shop made it all worth it. After the universe nearly ended, she could very much go for some sweet sugary confectioneries right about now. She saw them lined up neatly in the display -- so many different kinds! Glazed, chocolate iced, sprinkles, crullers, custard-filled, creme-filled, raspberry-filled...

"Oh my god," she breathed. "Just... there's just so many!"

"Paralyzed by indecision," the Doctor chuckled. "I felt the same way when picking out a new scarf."

The attendant behind the counter walked up to them. "Have you decided on your choice of doughnut, ma'am?"

Donna thought for a moment as she looked over what the place had to offer. She could feel the longing in her empty stomach as her taste buds cried out for everything. Her eyes glanced up at the menu options and scanned it: Single Doughnut, Three-Pack Doughnuts, Half a Dozen, A Dozen, The Challenge...

"What's 'The Challenge'?" she asked.

The attendant smiled. "That's the promotional offer we give. We have fifteen kinds of doughnuts, y'see, and if you can finish one of each kind, then you only have to pay for the price of a Single."

Donna mouth fell open in shock. "That's an option?! Bloody hell - has anyone ever managed it?"

"Oh, a few, depending on species. What do you think, miss? Are you up to the Challenge?"

Donna looked at the Doctor, who looked back at her with a shrug. "Up to you," he said.

"Do you think I can manage? I mean... I dunno, it's a bit daunting."

"So was defeating the Daleks, but you managed that. I have every faith in you." He grinned. "But then, I think you're brilliant, so maybe I'm biased," he added with a wink.

Donna nodded, then turned back to the attendant. "Challenge accepted," she said coolly.

The attendant nodded eagerly, then began to direct them to a table. "It'll be along shortly," he announced.

Donna pushed her chair back a bit to give her belly some room. "I'm gonna regret this tomorrow," she muttered, "but you know what -- I deserve this. I helped save the universe from a bunch of plunger-wielding pepper pots. I should splurge now and again."

"Hear, hear," said the Doctor. He pulled out a bottled water. "Here -- just to help you wash it down."

Donna took it and marveled that it was still cold. "How...?"

"I have a fridge in my coat pocket."

"..."

"Or maybe I nabbed it before we left the TARDIS."

She rolled her eyes but smiled. She had to appreciate how much a regular bloke he seemed to be now.

A few minutes later, a server arrived with fifteen doughnuts -- each a different kind -- and set the tray down on the table.

"The rules are simple," said the server. "All fifteen doughnuts must be consumed. No help from friends. You have one hour to finish. Are you ready?"

Donna took a deep breath and nodded.

The server set a stop watch. "All right. You may begin." She turned and left.

Donna looked at the small pyramid of doughnuts. So many different kinds. She started with the top one -- an original glazed -- and munched away at it. She finished it in nothing flat, and then plucked out the chocolate iced one. It didn't exactly sound like a lot. Fifteen doughnuts -- sounded easy enough. But she knew deep down the difference between fifteen doughnuts and, say, fifteen crisps. Doughnuts filled you up quicker.

She finished the chocolate-iced and picked up a vanilla-iced. Surprisingly, it tasted very good. She'd always been a hardcore chocolate girl. Felt like betraying chocolate to admit vanilla tasted just as good. She finished that one and grabbed the custard-filled.

The Doctor sat obediently on the other side of the small table, glancing out the window every so often while she pigged out. She wondered what must be going through his head while she did this. Probably something about how Time Lords would never degrade themselves like this and how small humans could be sometimes.

Then, he spoke. "I remember the last time I changed," he murmured.

Donna had just wiped the last bit of custard from her mouth. "... What?"

"The last time, when I became pinstripes and trainers. I had to absorb the time vortex itself out of Rose. That's where the whole Bad Wolf thing came from."

Donna blinked as she picked up the sprinkled doughnut and began to eat it. "How's that cause 'Bad Wolf'?"

"Well, with the power of the time vortex, she could send the message to herself throughout time and tell herself what to do. Stable time loop. So she broke into the TARDIS console and used the power of the vortex to destroy the Daleks. Also accidentally made Captain Jack immortal. Very human. Couldn't control it. So I took the power from her, and also took her death, causing me to regenerate."

Donna looked at him for a long moment. "Blimey," she said as she swallowed down the latest doughnut.

Then, he started talking about some of the other times he changed. Old age, forced by the Time Lords, radiation from a crystal cave, a nasty fall, Spectrox Toxamia, beams of radiation from the Rani... Didn't seem like he had any quiet or peaceful deaths.

Around the time he described his seventh regeneration -- which he seemed to regard as a rather embarrassing one -- she realized she had gotten through twelve doughnuts. She hadn't really noticed just how stuffed she felt. Only three more to go!

Then, she began to think -- maybe that's why he had started his stories: to distract her from feeling too full to finish. She felt a bit silly, taking that long to figure it out, but hey ho, it'd worked. She picked up a cruller and slowly shoved it into her mouth. Her belly already bulged so far forward, it almost pressed against the table. She got the cruller down and groaned.

"Oh god...," she moaned, gently hefting her swollen belly in her hands. "I don't think I can do this..."

"Pfft," the Doctor replied. "I think you can do anything. You're not gonna let a couple doughnuts slow you down, are you?"

Donna groaned, rubbing her stomach and taking a sip of water. Just a couple more. She took a few deep breaths and braced herself.

She took the maple-iced one. Never been a favorite, but she could fake it if she could just get through it. She chomped down on it, not letting a single crumb go to waste. Her stomach gurgled angrily at the addition, stretching even more as she swallowed it down. Her head lolled back as she let out a groan. She rubbed her stomach miserably and regarded the final doughnut.

Chocolate-iced creme-filled. One of the best doughnuts known to man.

The Doctor checked his watch. "Five minutes left," he warned her.

Donna whimpered. The doughnut sat there, taunting her. She didn't know if she could bring herself to reach down and finish it, but she knew what would happen if she didn't.

Donna moaned softly, but she forced herself to pick up the damn doughnut. She took it, took a bite, and relished the creamy filling. So gooey and sugary. She enjoyed the buzz it gave her.

She also felt her stomach gurgle in protest. She really wished she'd worn a dress, or at least an elastic waistband. She wailed sadly through her full mouth as she made herself swallow down the first bite.

The Doctor checked his watch. "Two minutes," he announced.

Donna glared at him but said nothing. She steeled her resolve and continued taking bites out of the doughnut, chewing slowly and carefully, too afraid to eat it too fast. She felt like she would pass out.

Then, she saw the look in the Doctor's eyes. That look that always encouraged people to be better than who they were, that could make anyone believe they were capable of greater things. That look that he always gave her when she needed that last bit of encouragement, be that fighting alien monsters like Sontarans or Daleks, or doing something ordinary like standing up to her mother or... eating doughnuts.

Steeling her resolve, she took the last half of the doughnut and shoved the whole thing in her mouth. She chewed, took a swig of water and swallowed.

"You did it!" cheered the Doctor excitedly.

Donna slumped back in her chair, her enormous stomach protruding far in front of her. She let out a sigh of relief, and almost immediately, the button gave, and the Doctor effortlessly snatched it out of the air before it hit his forehead. He didn't even look the slightest annoyed. He looked downright proud!

"Well done, Donna! I knew you could do it!"

Donna stared at him incredulously. She'd just almost caused him to regenerate again, and he seemed so much like a proud parent.

The serve came over and let out a whistle. "Very impressive!" she said. "Don't see a lot of human stomachs that can handle all that! Here's your prize!" She handed Donna a coupon. "Just show that whenever you're here, and you get free doughnuts!"

"Ooooh, very handy!" said the Doctor. "Makes it all worth it, eh, Donna?"

Donna tried to glare at him, but he was just adorable sometimes, so she allowed a small smile. "Yeah, worth it," she gasped. "Great doughnuts. Now... I need to lie down for about a thousand years."

The Doctor nodded and helped her out of her chair, bidding farewell to the staff as they clapped for her. She waved halfheartedly and leaned on him as they made it out the door and crossed the street back to the TARDIS.

"Well, I daresay this is another planet where you'll go down as a legendary hero," he said, pausing to put his hat on the stand before helping her the rest of the way.

"Yeah, t'rrific," she muttered. "Oh god, too much sugar. I need a break. Just need to... find somewhere to... sleep it off..."

"Right then," said the Doctor, guiding her towards the interior door. "Just trust the TARDIS -- she'll guide you to your room -- and get some shuteye, okay?"

"What? Sorry, I'm about to collapse..."

He smiled. "Goodnight, Donna."

"Oh yeah. G'night."

Leaving him in the control room, she made her way deeper into the ship. She could feel a tiny little nudge in the back of her mind, probably the TARDIS sending her in the right direction. At last, she found her room. Filled with relief, she kicked off her shoes and struggled out of her trousers, tossing them aside. She peered down at her belly. It protruded as if she'd swallowed a bowling ball. It felt so soft yet firm. She looked at herself in the mirror over her makeup table and couldn't help but marvel at how huge she'd become. She slid out of her top and stood in her underwear, admiring her bulging curves.

"Blimey," she murmured. "Turning into a right tub o' lard, aren't you?"

She ran her hands up and down her bodacious hips, and turned to examine her profile. Her belly bulged, her breasts sagged, and her butt wobbled furiously with every movement.

She felt a mischievous smile split her face. How would she hide all this from her mother?

"You gluttonous overeating overstuffed pig," she murmured, rubbing her stomach before the mirror. "Just look what you've gone and done. Mother would never approve."

She didn't know where all this came from, but it felt so good. To be out from under her mother's thumb, to be free from societal norms for a while...

She slowly settled onto the bed. To think she'd only been in Shan Shen this morning, happily gorging her way through the stalls. Then, of course, Time Beetle, Rose Tyler, Bad Wolf, Daleks, regeneration, Davros, etc, all happened, and with fifteen doughnuts filling up her stomach, she needed to sleep. She stripped out of the rest of her underwear and slid her bloated body into bed, which felt extra-comfortable thanks to her exhaustion.

Hand on her belly, she fell asleep.

When later she awoke...

Donna found some much bigger jeans in her closet and quietly thanked the TARDIS for preparing them. She got on a pullover and a jacket, did her hair up a bit, and then made tracks for the control room. After everything that happened in the last few days, she felt like relaxing for a bit. Her belly jiggled horizontally and vertically as she waddled up the long hexagonal corridors of the ship.

When she arrived, she briefly thought she'd entered the wrong room. Then, she saw the central column in the center and realized she'd got it right -- the room had somehow changed. Gone were the grated floors, coral struts and domed walls. In their place, she saw wood paneling and stained glass windows. The police box doors led from a long narrow pathway that stretched down a raised platform that met the main console, which sat on another wider platform, that then linked with the interior door she stood in. To her left stretched another raised pathway that led to a library with books, lamps and a couple chairs. To her left stretched a spiral staircase, the bottom of which led to another section beneath the main console.

The Doctor emerged from this underside, in his shirt and vest with thick rubber gloves and a pair of goggles. He hummed a jaunty tune until he saw her and smiled. "Donna! Good morning! Sleep well?"

Donna stared at him, then at the control room, and then back at him. "How the hell long was I asleep?!" she exclaimed.

He frowned, then realized what she was talking about. "Oh, this? You think you're tripping. I swear, I was only gone for five minutes, and here we are." He tilted his head. "Don't you like it?"

Donna looked at it again. Indeed, it was very pretty. Definitely cleaner than the grubby organic-looking control room he'd had before. Something spooky about it, but also kind of... cozy.

"... Still need to turn the heat up," she said, walking inside.

He let out an annoyed grunt before taking off the gloves and goggles and making for the controls. "Well, I just got the thermo-couplings set up, so we should be ready to resume traveling. Anyplace in mind today?" he asked, already working at the console.

Donna took a moment to note the console was much smaller than the old one. Perhaps he'd be able to fly it without having to dash about the room like a maniac. "I'd like to go home," she told him.

He looked up, alarmed. Then, he took a moment, and then asked, "For a visit?"

She smiled in amusement. "Yeah, I'm not done with you yet, Spaceman. I just need to check in on them. They sounded all right on the phone, but it'd be good to see them again."

He smiled. "Right. Off to Chiswick. I'll aim for an hour after the Earth returned home." He set the controls and the new time rotor rose and fell.

Ten minutes later, they felt the TARDIS bump into a landing, and he grabbed his hat and scarf as they headed for the door.

"Right! How do I look?" he asked.

Donna looked him up and down with a shrug. "You look fine. Why?"

"Well, it's their first time seeing me with this face. Wanna make a good second first impression."

She rolled her eyes fondly. "We'll try and explain what happened, all right? They'll come around. Plus, Mum knows you're an alien now, so maybe that'll widen her narrow little mind."

The Doctor gave a small smile before straightening his jacket. "Right then, let's get going." He snapped his fingers, and the doors popped open.

"Show off," she muttered.

"Always," he replied cheerfully, doffing his hat briefly.

They set out into the warm summer air and walked up the street to her house. The Doctor took one last moment to get himself ready before following her up the steps to the house.

Donna rang the bell. She heard her granddad yelling her name as his footsteps clomped up to the door and yanked it open.

"There's my girl!" cheered Wilf, pulling her into a hug.

"Gramps!" she said, hugging him right back. "Everyone all right?"

"Yeah, 'course we are," he replied, holding her tight. "Everyone's fine." He looked over her shoulder. "Oh, hello," he said. "Who's this?"

Donna braced herself. "Granddad...," she said slowly. "This is the Doctor."

The Doctor politely raised his hat in greeting. "Hello again, Wilfred."

Wilf stared at him in stunned silence. "Doctor...?"

"Donna!"

Donna jumped at the familiar voice, but she saw the relieved smile on her mother's face and melted. She pulled her mother into a huge hug.

"Oh my girl, my sweet girl, thank god you're home," she squealed, rocking her back and forth.

"I'm fine, mum. I'm fine," Donna laughed.

Then, Sylvia glanced over her shoulder. "Who's he?"

"She says it's the Doctor," said Wilf, still looking spellbound.

"Hello!" said the Doctor, raising his hat once again.

"Oh, don't be ridiculous!" said Sylvia. "How can he be the Doctor?!"

"Well, he sort of got... shot by a Dalek," said Donna, "but it's okay because he can regenerate."

"What does that even mean?!"

"It means when his old body dies, he can change into a new... not-dying body. He just looks a bit different, that's all."

They all stared at him again, and he simply smiled and raised his hat a third time. "Hello!"

Wilf finally shrugged. "Well, if our Donna says it's the Doctor, that's good enough for me. Come on in, Doctor."

The Doctor smiled and followed him into the house, putting his hat on the rack as they went into the living room.

Donna stood next to Sylvia before glancing at her again, wondering what her mother would say. The usual stern expression was replaced with one of genuine concern. After another moment, her mother found her voice.

Twenty minutes later, dinner was ready, and Donna knew she'd never be able to resist gorging herself silly. Might as well take advantage of her mother's understanding mood while it lasted.

They called the Doctor and Wilf in to join them, and after setting the table, conversation started. Naturally, her family wanted answers on what happened with the Daleks, what they were and what their beef with the Doctor was. He gave them the family-friendly version -- leaving out most details of the Time War and everything horribly depressing, and mostly focusing on the several times he'd defeated them. He also talked a bit about regeneration and how it worked, how many times he'd done it and what it meant for his future.

Donna felt relieved she didn't have to talk so much. His chatterbox nature meant she was free to eat. Her mother always cooked enough food to feed a small army. Of course, she always criticized her for eating too much of it, and complaining when she didn't eat enough of it. She didn't care about that right now -- she wanted to eat as much as possible. She piled on the lasagna, the steamed vegetables, the casserole and set to work eating it down.

It was a long job. Her mother had always been a fabulous cook. She ate everything slowly enough to savor it all. She knew the Doctor would keep Wilf and Sylvia entertained enough that she'd only really need to thrown in occasionally.

"Well, if he's going to go about like that, he's going to need some new clothes," Sylvia said.

"I'm wearing new clothes!" the Doctor objected.

"She's saying you need to ditch the plaid," Donna said between mouthfuls.

"What's wrong with plaid? It's Scotland's official color!"

"Not in those colors."

To her surprise, her mother laughed. "You're gonna have to get him 'round to the new shopping mall. Do him up a bit."

"Oh god, try shopping with this bloke is nearly impossible. Try taking him to a mall, and he disappears in under fifteen seconds. Once found him trying to tinker with a massage chair with his screwdriver."

"Only trying to improve performance!" the Doctor retorted.

"You nearly got arrested!"

Dinner continued in with more stories -- both from outer space and right here on Earth -- while Donna continued her assault on dinner. Every time it looked like she was finishing up, she'd reach for more, piling her plate high. She didn't care if she made an utter pig of herself in front of her family. She'd saved the bloody universe. She deserved to let loose for a change.

Speaking of 'loose', her pants felt anything but at the moment. As her belly expanded, she felt the trousers get tighter around it. They'd felt so freeing when she'd got dressed, and already, she felt like she was bursting out of them. Part of her felt embarrassed over this, but another part felt thrilled. She wondered how far she had to go before she swelled up enough to pop the button. She remembered her turn in the wardrobe room a few weeks ago when she popped all the buttons off those skinny clothes. The idea that she could do the same to 'fat' clothes seemed like a challenge.

All too soon, though, the food was depleted, and the Doctor offered to help Sylvia tidy it away. Good thing, too, because Donna simply could not move. She quietly tried to rub her stomach, which felt rock hard from all the food inside it. She chatted with Wilf a bit, catching up on his latest misadventures, grateful for a chance to sit and relax.

Then, to her astonishment, dessert was served. Her mother put a chocolate pie in the middle of the table and cut slices for everyone.

Blimey, thought Donna. She really isn't all that concerned with my weight right now.

She briefly wasn't sure she could do it, but then, she remembered the doughnuts and knew she could. She started eating up the delectable slice with relish. The thick chocolatey-ness of it -- it made her swoon. She continued eating it, and all too soon, it was gone. Her chocolate craving was nowhere near satisfied. She licked her lips at the remaining pie. More than half. She wondered if she could do it. Then, she decided that she didn't care. She was going to try.

Donna subtly hooked the pie tin with her fork and edged it closer to her plate. She quietly started cutting into the pie. The Doctor was telling a story about Sontarans and medieval knights and disappearing scientists, and it provided just enough cover for her to finish the pie without attracting too much attention. She ate her first piece, and then that segued into the second, and then that headed into the third. Her stomach felt utterly miserable as it swelled inside those trousers, and she didn't care a jot. She could do it.

At last, she was down to the final piece. She took a sip of water before taking her fork and simply eating it out of the tin. The Doctor was wrapping up his story, talking about how there'd been dinosaurs in 1970s London -- or was it the 80s? -- and how he talked Sarah Jane into traveling with him. She managed to get the last bit of crust into her mouth and smiled as the others laughed at the end of the story.

"Well," said Sylvia, "I don't know about the rest of you, but I could do with a rest after today."

"Hear hear," agreed Wilf. "I need a sit down and possibly a nap."

The Doctor nodded. "Could do with a bit of rest myself," he said. "Maybe work on my new screwdriver. Been meaning to make a new one." He looked over at Donna, who tried not to look too stuffed and bloated. "Donna? How about you? Back to the TARDIS? Or do you want to stay here for the night?"

Donna stifled and belch and considered.

When Donna's eyes popped open, the sun had gone down and ensconced her bedroom in total darkness. She panicked briefly, but then, she remembered the day's previous events. Her mother's cooking, eating so much she needed to lie down, passing out naked in her own bed. Her eyes darted around until she spotted the digital alarm clock on her bedside table. Not long after midnight now. Nearly one in the morning. She rolled over in bed to reach the lamp, and as she switched it on, she felt the contents in her belly shift.

With the light on, she peered under the sheets and found her big round belly peering back at her. She ran her free hand along it, enjoying the curves and bulges. It still amazed her that she felt such pride and joy in her growing size. In fact, it thrilled her. It felt like she'd finally shaken off the restrictive shackles of shallowness enforced on her since a young age. She could finally be herself. She could finally eat what she wanted without worrying what others thought.

After a few minutes, her stomach gurgled, and she felt a stab of hunger. She winced slightly -- it had been a few hours since dinner, and she'd slept off most of her gorge. She thought maybe she could do with a snack. Just pop down real quick and enjoy a few nibbles of whatever her mother had in the fridge. Enough to hold her over 'til breakfast. Surely there would be enough to keep her stomach calm until then. Her stomach gurgled again. She hoped it wouldn't take much to satisfy it.

She swung her meaty thighs out of bed and waddled over to her dresser. She slipped into a pair of old sweats -- which were just a tad too small but whatever -- and put on her biggest t-shirt -- which allowed her gut to hang out by two clear inches -- and got on her slippers before peeking her head out the door and making sure the coast was clear. She didn't know why she felt the need to snack in secret, but she had to admit it was more exciting this way. She tiptoed into the hall and headed downstairs.

Once there, she padded softly into the kitchen and turned on the under-cabinet lights. She'd have to be quiet, lest her mother wake up and hear the noise. She made a beeline for the fridge and pulled it open, bathing herself in the white light. Her eyes lit up at the full fridge. So much to choose from. Her mother must've gone shopping just before the Earth got taken. Fruit and veg, meat, dairy, grain, sweets -- all the food groups amply represented within the cool chamber. She licked her lips and started digging.

She told herself she needed something healthy in her diet. Couldn't just live off doughnuts and pasta, after all. She grabbed a stick of celery and chomped down on it hungrily, and once that proved not even remotely filling, she grabbed a bag of baby carrots and gobbled several of those down as well. Still not satisfied, she looked around and spotted some apples on the counter. She ate three in less than ten minutes and tossed the cores, but health foods weren't doing it.

Then, she saw the sliced turkey and a loaf of bread and thought maybe that would prove more filling. She grabbed the turkey, the cheese, the mustard and the mayo and proceeded to make herself a sandwich. She enjoyed it much more than the vegetables, but she finished it far too quickly, so she made another one. That gave way to a third one, and then a fourth before she finally got bored with the taste. She patted her stomach as she tidied away the knife she'd used, but it still wasn't enough.

She went through the pantry and found a box of her favorite cereal. Maybe that would help. She got down a bowl and poured it into the bowl. She poured the milk as well and got going. Wonderfully cool and crunchy. She hadn't had since before she left with the Doctor. She had two bowls and a few slugs of milk straight from the gallon, but even as her belly protruded further, that need to eat persisted. She didn't know why she felt such a strong need to keep eating, but it felt too powerful to ignore.

Returning to the pantry, she went through a few other snacks. Some crackers, some chocolate covered biscuits, some bananas... Nothing seemed to calm her hunger. She wondered what could possibly satisfy her at this point. Could she really be so mindlessly gluttonous that nothing would satisfy her? How much more could she eat before she ended up eating her mother and granddad out of house and home? She worried about this as she microwaved herself some fish fingers and chomped through them all.

Then, her eyes fell on the fridge again. She hadn't exactly given it a thorough inspection. She pulled it open again and peered inside. Must be something she'd missed. She took a few swigs of apple juice while she looked, and then, her eyes fell on what she'd missed -- the remains of the second chocolate pie her mother had made. She bit her lip. If she ate it, no doubt her mother would know who took it. She looked at it with longing and glanced at her stomach -- already so swollen. She shouldn't.

But she did. She took the pie and began to eat it, right there in the open fridge. She whimpered with desire as she chewed, eating face down in the tin like a pig. She greedily at the whole thing, slurping and munching, before finally finishing it all off. She gently placed the empty tin on the counter before taking a few chugs of milk. She felt her sweats get a bit tighter around her middle. She put the milk back and began to tidy things away. Her stomach gave a gurgle, this time from being full.

As she threw the tin in the recycling, she began to feel full. Re-e-e-e-e-eally full. So full it hurt. The pie had satisfied the hunger, but now her poor tummy felt far too full after being so utterly jam packed with food. She moaned sadly and stifled a belch as she turned off the lights and waddled slowly and miserably back to the stairs. She gripped the railing tightly and practically dragged herself up to the hallway. She winced as her new weight made everything creak, but she found her door.

Once inside her room, she shut the door and made for the bed, already pulling off the shirt and lowering the now far-too-tight stretch pants. She turned and looked at her profile in the mirror, and the difference was staggering. She'd gone from a bit plump to six months pregnant in less than an hour. She ran her hands up and down the magnificent curve and marveled for a minute. Then, her stomach gurgled, making her moaned and stifle another belch. She kicked off her sweats and turned to the bed.

Easing herself between the cool sheets, she took her time positioning herself. She didn't want to move too suddenly for fear of losing all that gorging. She settled down and slowly rolled over to turn her lamp off. Her stomach got in the way for a time, but she managed to reach it and turn it off, plunging her room back into darkness. Sighing with relief, full of food and hands atop her big belly, she settled back into the covers and went back to sleep. She just hoped her mother didn't raise hell over he pie.
