The next time Donna awoke, she saw the sun peeking in through the curtains. She glanced at the clock and saw it to be just after eight. Sighing heavily and stretching her aching muscles, she turned and swung her legs out over the edge of the bed and heaved herself upright. She rubbed her eyes and lightly slapped her belly, taking note of just how much of her lap it took up. Halfway to her knees. She shook her head. She could only imagine what her mother would make of the eaten food from her late night gorge.

Digging through her clothes, she found that absolutely nothing could possibly contain her newfound girth, so she went for the sweats again and put on a nice sweater with an light overcoat, in the hopes that it would deflect attention from her belly. They weren't perfect, but they made her curves less noticeable. She'd worry about a new bra when she got to the TARDIS. She knew she had to at least have breakfast with her family before she took off for the deepest reaches of time and space.

Once fully dressed, she opened the door and made her way towards the stairs. Before she'd even descended the first step, she could smell something heavenly. Smelled like... eggs and bacon and... pancakes? Seriously? Her mother cooking pancakes? She couldn't even remember the last time she'd had pancakes in this house. She could hear voices as well. Her gramps, her mother and... the Doctor?! She still couldn't get used to that nasally American accent of his. But what was he doing here so early?

When she made it to the kitchen, she came up short. Her mother and grandfather sat around the table, and the Doctor stood over the stove, making what appeared to be the world's most elaborate omelette with bacon and pancakes brewing as well. He seemed to be in the midst of some story, regaling her family with a tale from long before he knew her. Something involving someone named 'Jo' and a bunch of shop window dummies and plastic flowers and some bloke called 'the Master'.

He turned and saw her entering. "Donna!" he said cheerily. "Just in time! Almost done! Have a seat!"

Donna knew she was gawping, but she couldn't help it. "You're here early," she remarked with a startled laugh. "Didn't know you could cook."

"Me neither!" he replied, before briefly experimenting with the different pronunciations of the word 'neither'. "Still not used to the voice! Here! Sit down! Breakfast time!"

Donna smiled and sat between her mother and gramps. The Doctor hummed a little ditty and began serving. Omelettes, bacon and pancakes all around. Donna couldn't help but notice how he put a few extra pancakes on her plate, but she couldn't tell if he'd done it for some underhanded reason or simply because he liked her best. In any case, he sat down and continued his story, getting to the part where a giant plastic chair had tried to eat him alive.

Donna cut a small piece and took a bite of the omelette. To her relief, it tasted amazing. Must be some alien recipe because she didn't recognize it at all. She began eating more and more of it with joy, reveling in the unique spices and delightful flavor. Her family clearly enjoyed it as well, eating up every last bite while he finished his story and babbled on aimlessly into the next one. She ate up her bacon and started in on the pancakes. Five, he'd given her, while everyone else got two. She sneaked a glance at her mother for any signs of judgement, but she seemed more concerned with asking the Doctor questions as he described his metal dog.

As the coast was clear, Donna surreptitiously hooked the small syrup container with her pinky and began to smother her pancakes in maple goodness, followed by a few slices of butter. She still managed to listen to the story and chime in at the appropriate times. After all, he'd been so damn quiet before the change. Talked a lot, but never really said anything. She liked this storyteller side of him -- so much history to be found in him. Good to know there were good memories as well.

Still, she kept at the pancakes. She got the first one down with little effort, but the second one proved a tad more taxing. Such a big breakfast, and such big portions. Appropriate, really, seeing as how she'd become such a big girl lately. Had she always been like this, deep down? A closet glutton? Was this her finding the nerve to "come out", as it were? All these years of watching her waist, and she'd been suppressing the real her all along. She wanted food -- the waistline be damned.

Donna continued into the breakfast feast. The second one finished down her gullet, and the third made its way as well. She set to work on the fourth and silently thanked whatever higher deities existed that she'd worn the sweats. But even those had limits, and she could feel her stomach swelling behind the waistband. She took a swig of orange juice and continued. She noticed her breathing becoming a tad more labored and tried to keep it even. No need to draw attention to herself. Just keep chewing.

The final pancake stared her down. She cut it up and started eating it. God, she felt full, but she didn't want to show it. And she didn't want to not finish these amazing pancakes. She wondered if she could convince the Doctor to cook like this all the time. She wondered if the regeneration had tuned his personality to suit hers more. A bit more snark, a bit more candid, and a half-decent cook to boot. She continued munching away, the American nasal beginning to grow on her just a bit.

At last, she'd finished her breakfast, and after a few more hearty sips of orange juice, she slumped back in the chair and resisted the urge to rub her stomach. It bulged so enormously, she looked like she'd swallowed a basketball. Probably had her own gravitational pull. The TARDIS could go into orbit around her. She smiled slightly at the thought of being the size of a planet and the little blue police box circling her once a year. She pulled down her sweater and stifled a belch as everyone finished.

Not long after that, the Doctor helped tidy everything away and do the dishes while she chatted with her family. They came to some agreements -- call at least twice a week, send pictures, visit more often and give them a heads up if the world started ending again. She agreed to those terms and gave them both the longest hugs. She liked it when home felt like home. Somewhere she could rely on and feel safe from outside annoyances. She hoped her mother's good mood continued into the near future.

After fifteen minutes of hugging, she finally made her way out the door, and she followed the Doctor up the sidewalk towards the TARDIS.

"So...," she drawled, "... what'd you get up to while I was away?"

The Doctor looked mildly startled. "What makes you think I got up to anything?"

She gave him a knowing look, and he grinned sheepishly.

"Well, I rewrote my symposium on the lifespan of the universe -- all in jokes -- before helping out with a small county hospital in the Beleros Sphere and saved a planet from a horde of Demon Spider Monkeys." He reached into his pocket and pulled out a cylindrical device that made a familiar whirring noise. "Oh! And I got a new sonic screwdriver! Look, the light's purple now!"

Donna laughed. "God, you just can't sit still for a minute, can you?"

"To be honest, it was a relief to just sit back and have breakfast after all that."

"How long were you gone?"

"Oh, just a few days from my point of view. Couldn't stay away that long. Too damn quiet in that TARDIS without you."

"Aww, I'm touched."

They made it back, but rather than open the door with his key, he snapped his fingers, and they swung open. She smiled slightly and followed him inside. He made the walk up to the console and began pressing a few buttons.

"So, where to next?" she asked, lazily thumping down in his easy chair.

"Dunno," he replied, fiddling with the controls. He pulled the main lever, and that funny wheezing noise sounded as they entered the time vortex. "Let's fly about a bit and see if anything comes our way."

Donna nodded as she absently lowered her stretch pants, allowing her (once again) overstuffed belly to spill out into her lap. More like three quarters to her knees now. She sat contentedly, hands atop her stomach and listening to the lovely sounds of the TARDIS as she nodded off.

Donna awoke to a rather sudden bump as the TARDIS landed. She'd nodded off in the chair, and she gripped both arm rests in alarm, nearly ruining the fake-leather with her nails. She sat upright and looked around, noticing straight away that her stomach still stuck out from her too-tight stretch pants and her rolled-up sweater. Panicking, she pulled her sweater down again and tried to get herself looking decent. She managed to heave the suck in her gut long enough to get the elastic up and over it, but when she exhaled, she seemed to have two rather large bulges across her middle as they creased the middle of her belly.

Deciding that would have to do, she got to her feet and waddled awkwardly up from the reading area to the console platform. The Doctor popped up from behind the wood-paneled console and checked the monitor. "Here we are!" he said, flipping some switches. "Victorian London -- for your viewing pleasure!" He turned the monitor so she could have a look as well. She saw a very white screen.

Then, a gust of wind revealed the white to be snow. They'd landed under a bridge, but she could see the activity taking place. People laughing, singing, shopping, with lots of top hats and skirts and chickens. She quietly marveled for a few moments before she began to register just how many corsets the women wore. All of them walking about like having their innards squeezed stupid wasn't the debilitating business it really was. She glanced down at her plumpness and squirmed.

"Do I have to dress up?" she asked.

The Doctor blinked. "Do you want to?"

"Not particularly."

"Well then!" He grabbed his fedora and plaid black-and-white scarf and slipped on his black sport coat. "Let's get going!"

Donna felt a small smile. "I don't have to dress up?"

"Nah, not to worry. Just walk around like you own the place. It's always worked for me."

Donna nodded, but then she remembered what she had on. "Er... just let me get some neater clothes on. I slept in these."

"Sure," he shrugged. "I'll get some info on the area."

Donna hurried off to the wardrobe room. To her immense relief, the TARDIS seemed to have moved it much closer than normal, and she darted inside, already pulling her sweater off. She hoped against hope that maybe she'd be provided with some clothes in her size for a change. To her relief, she found a thicker sweater that covered her properly, and a pair of plus size jeans that actually seemed capable of holding together when she squatted. Finishing it off with a thick jacket, she hurried back again.

Once she'd made it outside, she tried to find him, and immediately found him having some sort of spirited discussion with a chicken. Honest to god clucking with a chicken, like a bloody Muppet. She slowly approached, half out of shock and half out of decency. After a few moments, he tipped his hat to the chicken, looked around briefly, and then lit up when he saw her and approached. She briefly considered pretending she'd never seen him before.

"What the hell was that?" she asked.

"Just getting the details on where we are," he replied with a shrug.

"From a chicken?"

"Always get to know the local color when you're time traveling, Donna. Wealth of information."

"But a chicken?!"

"What's wrong with chickens?"

"What, you just 'speak chicken'?"

"I speak everything."

Donna rolled her eyes. "And what did the chicken say?"

"That it's 1851, it's Christmas Eve and to stop blocking her view of the cockerel in the cage across from her."

"Oh, a cheeky chicken, eh?"

Just then, they heard a woman's voice cut across the marketplace. "DOCTOR!"

They both looked around at the voice. It seemed to be coming from up an alleyway.

"... Who, me?" the Doctor asked, confused.

The voice shouted again. "DOCTOR!!"

With a shrug, he turned and ran towards the voice. Donna groaned. She really didn't want to run right now. Clasping her stomach in both hands to prevent it from jiggling too much, she tore after him up the alley. When they arrived, they found a young dark-skinned woman doing all the shouting while she stood before a door that rattled and shook madly.

"DOCT-AHHHHHH!!" the woman kept screaming.

"Yes, sorry, I'm here!" the Doctor said, trying to shield her from the door. "What've we got here?"

"Who are you?!"

"I'm the Doctor!"

"Doctor who?!"

"Just the Doctor. Donna -- maybe you should take her away from here."

"But what's behind the door?" Donna demanded, trying to get her breath back.

At that moment, another man in a frock coat and waistcoat came running up, looking quite exhilarated.

"Where've you been?!" the woman demanded.

"Right then, don't worry, stand back, what have we got here then...?" he asked in a great booming voice.

"Who the hell are you?!" Donna asked incredulously.

The other man grinned at her. "I'm the Doctor! Simply the Doctor! The one, the only, and the best!" he said with a wink. The door boomed again, and he held out a hand to the woman. "Rosita! Pass me the sonic screwdriver!"

The Doctor continued to reel in shock. "Who? The what??"

"Now quickly! Get back to the TARDIS!"

"Back to the what?!"

"If you would stand back, sir! This is a job for a Time Lord!"

"Job for a what Lord?!"

With a loud bang, the doors burst open, and Donna jumped back as a strange black-furred creature with a metallic face burst out, growling furiously.

"Oh, that's new!" both Doctors said at once. Both pulled out their screwdrivers and aimed.

"Allons-y!" said the other Doctor.

Donna's mouth fell open, as did the Doctor's. The snarling thrashing creature got their attention, though.

"What is it?" Donna demanded. "What's it doing here?"

"It's fallen right into my trap!" the other Doctor said with great bravado. "Oh, I've been hunting this beast for a good fortnight, now step back, sir -"

The creature responded by leaping over them and clinging to the wall, not unlike Spiderman. The other Doctor tried lassoing it with a rope, but it simply lifted him up, and then it proceeded to list up the Doctor when he tried to grab it. The rope continued to climb when Donna had a frankly brilliant idea. Acting quickly, she waddled over and grabbed the rope, wrapping her wrists around it. With her added poundage weighting it down, the creature began sliding down the wall, scrabbling furiously to continue climbing. Taking advantage of the distraction, the Doctor managed to reach into his coat pocket and pull out his screwdriver and gave the creature a quick whirrr! It briefly shuddered before the metal face sparked, and it slid the rest of the way down, allowing them all to land in a big heap at the bottom of the building, the creature having gone limp.

Rosita helped them all get up. "Are you okay?" she asked the other Doctor.

The other Doctor simply laughed heartily. "All the better for finally having this beastie under control at last, and all thanks to our new friends here!" He turned and helped the Doctor and Donna to their feet. "Well done, both of you! Very brave!"

"Yeah, cheers," grunted Donna, rubbing her considerable rump. "So, back up -- you're the Doctor?"

"Indeed, madam!" he said. "And you are?"

Donna blinked and slowly replied, "Donna Noble. Do you not know me?"

"Should I?"

She looked to her Doctor, who raised a fascinated eyebrow. "Well, frankly, yes," he said. "You don't recognize either of us?"

"Never seen you before in my life."

Donna could already tell they would be here a while.

To cut a long story short, the "Doctor" turned out to be a man named Jackson Lake, who'd had his mind scrambled due to a combination of a backfiring infostamp full of Doctor data backfired into his head and the trauma of his wife's death both happening at roughly the same time. They'd managed to find the Cybermen, who'd been working with a woman named Miss Hartigan to kidnap all the children in town to use them as a workforce to power up a huge steampunk Cyberman. Fortunately, the real Doctor saved the town using a gas balloon and thing that made a bunch of swirly wibbly things around the giant Cyberman and transported it... somewhere. But London was saved (again) and everyone celebrated in the streets amidst the destruction, already starting to rebuild. Jackson had his son back at least.

Donna walked with the Doctor and Jackson through the crowds, taking in the sights.

"The City will recover. As London always does. Though today's events will be history! Spoken of for centuries to come!"

"Yeah...," murmured the Doctor, looking at something. "Funny, that." Donna followed his eyeline and saw he was looking at a great big crack in a wall, and was it her imagination or was it actually glowing...?

Jackson continued. "And a new history begins for me. I find myself a widower. But with my son, and with good friends."

They glanced back at Rosita, who stood with young Frederick and waved at them.

"But you're welcome to join us. We thought we might all dine together, at the Traveller's Halt, a Christmas feast, in celebration, and in memory of those we have lost..."

The Doctor's expression turn wistful. "Those we've lost," he repeated. Then, he shrugged. "Oh, why not? What do you think, Donna?"

Donna blinked, not used to the Doctor agreeing to stay for once. She found her voice. "Yeah, might be fun," she said at last. After all, she hadn't eaten in hours, and she could do with some food, even if it was Victorian era food, and she agreed she wasn't ready to leave their new friends just yet.

Following Jackson to the Traveller's Halt, Donna found it to be a bustling hub of people, taking food from a buffet line and talking excitedly about the earlier activity. She got a plate and got a grilled turkey leg with some sprouts and potatoes. Pretty decent, really. She noticed, however, that folks were getting mugs of ale from a nearby giant barrel. Realizing she needed a decent drink after the last few days, she took a chance on it. She took a mug and got herself a drink.

She took a sip and right away felt herself loosen up. This stuff tasted amazing. She ate her dinner in utter contentment, listening as the Doctor chatted with Jackson and all the other people at the table, talking about the Cybermen, not to mention some of the other adventures he'd had while Jackson talked about the other things he'd done as "the Doctor".

Donna, however, could barely listen. The ale tasted incredible and gave her such a warm feeling. Like, all the stress she'd built up traveling melted away like ice in global warming. She finished her mug and immediately went for a refill. No one seemed to be manning the tap, so she immediately helped herself. It tasted just as warm and delicious as the first one. Excellent protection against the cold. She smiled politely as a few other patrons got themselves a glass or two, making a point not to look at them too closely, before getting herself a third. She gulped it down in nothing flat, feeling more and more loose with each drink.

The night wore on, and people came and went, but Donna remained where she was, constantly refilling her mug. She kept a low profile, not wanting to draw too much attention to herself, but as she continued to drink, she felt her inhibitions lowering considerably. Then, to her disappointment, she put her mug under the tap for another glass and found it empty. She couldn't have had that much, could she? She usually knew how to not overdo it, and that hadn't felt like that much.

Her drink-addled brain thought it over. Must be more somewhere, right? A tavern would definitely have more. She felt like looking for more would be stupid, but with so much ale sloshing around inside her, she found she didn't care. She peeked around to make sure no one saw her before slipping behind the barrel and spying an open door with no one standing around. She spotted the Doctor still chatting with the townspeople and took her chance for queen and country. She slid through and surreptitiously slipped inside.

Listening to her belly slosh with what she'd already consumed, Donna waddled into the darkened cellar. Her eyes adjusted to the darkness before she found a candle and lit it with her lighter. She found what she sought. Enormous barrels of beer, wine and all things good and alcoholic. The logical part of her brain told her this was stupid and she should just leave. The reasonable part told her that a few drinks wouldn't kill her. The hedonist part of brain told her to drink merrily.

Donna smiled up at the giant barrel in front of her, placed on a rack with all the others. She found the one labelled 'ale' and found it had a spigot on the front, all set for pouring its contents into her mug. She double-checked that she was alone, with no one about to come down the stairs, and once content, she took her mug and put it under the spigot, turned the handle and let it fill up. Once her mug had all it could hold, she twisted the knob back and took a nice long drink. She let out a contented sigh after the first sip before returning to chugging it again.

She leaned herself against the barrels and continued on the one she'd found. It had been far too long since the last time she'd had a proper drinking session like this. She could dimly recall a pub crawl with some friends on a hen night, but that had been a long time ago. She looked around in the darkness and felt a stab of alcohol enhanced sadness. Drinking alone. Sad, really. Pity the Doctor didn't seem to drink.

That made her giggle in a silly way. She tried to imagine the Doctor getting drunk. She remembered the man he'd been before only had the odd ginger beer or banana daiquiri, but he only occasionally. The new Doctor didn't seem to drink a drop of alcohol at all. In fact, the most exciting thing he drank in her presence was ice water with some lemon squeezed in it. Disappointing, really. Sure, she didn't really miss hangovers, but she missed going out with her mates and guzzling herself into a stupor.

Remembering why she was here, she poured herself another glass. Her stomach sloshed like a waterbed from all she'd consumed recently. She rubbed her gut and giggled stupidly at the contents gurgling away. She finished the second glass and started in on the third. She sipped it down and felt something deep inside of her go a little mad. She'd gone without for so long that she needed more. With no Doctor to be a buzzkill and no mother to struggle to avoid at home, she saw no reason not to go mad.

She set the mug down on the floor along side the candle. Her heart pounded with excitement as she considered what she was about to do. She knew she had to be careful, even if she was blitzed out of her mind. She licked her lips and eased herself down, already too full to risk doing anything too acrobatic like bending over. She eased herself onto her rump and reached up for the spigot. She wrapped her fingers around the handle and gave it the gentlest of twists. Too much, and she'd drown. Easy does it.

A gentle stream of ale poured into her mouth. She let out a gargled groan of joy and drank it down, leaning back and relaxing every muscle. She gulped down the steady stream of warm liquid and rubbed her swelling belly. She could feel how hard it already was, so utterly packed like a giant water balloon. She reached down and unbuttoned her trousers, too drunk off her ass to even think about the consequences to her actions anymore. She moaned softly as it continued, her belly stretching outwards.

She could feel herself getting bigger, and that caused a great deal of nonsense from downstairs. She fought back another groaned as she slipped one hand down into her unbuttoned trousers and felt around, trying to assuage that strange tingle that came from within. The 'thunder from down under', as it were. She felt so utterly full, but she didn't care -- she wanted this. She needed this. She wanted to be as big around as this bloody barrel she guzzled from. Must have more...

But now she felt too full. Past the enjoyable part and into the utterly miserable part. She let out one last sad moan and reached up, turning the spigot once again. The flow ceased, and she sat in a pathetic puddle on the floor, still fiddling around her undercarriage and biting her lip to keep from moaning. Her stomach didn't even jiggle. Hard as a rock. She couldn't budge an inch. She didn't care. She just needed to feel... just... a little... longer...

...

Okay, got that done, she thought with immense relief, wiping her hand off in the puddle she sat in. Her front soaked and her belly protruding like a globe, not to mention the pleasant throbbing down below, she struggled to realize just how sloshed she was. Her head swam groggily and her body felt like lead. Still, the one thing she managed to remember -- she couldn't stay down here indefinitely. Someone would find her and start to ask a lot of awkward questions. She had to find her way out of here soon.

She rocked herself back and forth a little to get some movement -- and also, to listen to that wonderful sloshing sound her belly made -- she got herself moving forward and onto her hands and knees. Good enough, she decided. She got hold of the still-lit candle, deciding to just abandon the mug, and awkwardly dragged herself along the cold hard floor for the steps she'd found earlier. She couldn't hear much activity upstairs. Maybe the party had ended and everyone had gone home. Fine with her.

Except... the Doctor wouldn't leave without her, would he? Wouldn't just assume she'd gone back to the TARDIS to sleep it off? No, of course not. He wouldn't assume anything. He'd think to go looking for her. She focused on getting out of the cellar first. Get upstairs, sneak out and get into the open. Maybe the cold air would help her think clearly. Just had to finish crawling down this absurdly long corridor. Would it ever end? It must've been hours. Or maybe minutes. Hell, maybe seconds.

Her stomach sloshed and gurgled beneath her, trying to contain the massive binge she'd just guzzled. A few cobblestones were uneven, and her gut hung so low that it gently brushed against their cool surface. She tried to ignore how nice it felt. She needed to get up those stairs. Not focus on how swollen she was. How big and round and fat she was. What a big fat greedy piggy she was. Whatever would the Doctor say when he saw the state she'd gotten herself in. He'd be ever so disappointed.

She found the bottom stair and gripped it with relief. She blew out the candle. She probably wouldn't need it now. Besides, she'd probably light the way with the blush she sported. Did she really just think of the Doctor like that? She'd had a hard enough thinking of him as a sexual being when he looked what some might call 'stereotypically handsome'. Now he looked dorky and awkward and too tall and funny hair and foreboding-yet-adorable brow and kinda grumpy, which only made those genuine smiles of his even cuter and...

Must be the alcohol, she decided. Only explanation. Why else would she suddenly start having sexual thoughts about the Doctor. He wasn't her type at all. Best friends. Nothing more. No interest in a long term relationship. Neither of them. Still... sometimes best mates got together. Despite what half a dozen rom coms might tell society, it was in fact possible to have sex with friends and not feel anything. She didn't make a habit of it, but the possibility was there...

She realized she'd made it to the top of the stairs, and she found herself in the darkened tavern. Not a soul in sight. She was totally alone. No one at all. She felt sad. He'd left without saying goodbye. She heaved herself forwards towards the bar and used a few discarded chairs to force herself to stand. She didn't quite make it and began to stumble back down again until...

Chums. Pals. That's it. She took a shower to brace herself, then got dressed in some sensible clothes and walked towards the control room.

Steeling her resolve, she walked over and, upon not being noticed, cleared her throat. "Ahem." The work stopped, and he slid out, peering up at her. He didn't say anything, nor did his expression yield any inner thoughts. She bit her lip awkwardly and wrapped her arms around herself, ready to begin.

"Can we talk?" she asked quietly.

"Of course," he replied, sliding all the way out and getting to his feet. He leaned against the console and waited.

"So...," Donna said slowly. "Last night... wasn't great."

The Doctor shrugged but didn't say anything.

"I don't know what happened, really. I just... Once I got a taste for it, I couldn't stop, and I know I should've shown more self-control and been more careful, especially in another bloody century, but I... It felt so good to just cut loose for a night. Like, I could finally just be free after all those years under my mum's thumb and society judging me and trying to keep myself up to everybody else's standards and I... I just wanted to be free, and I felt free, and I didn't want it to end..."

The Doctor nodded, hopefully with understanding, so she continued.

"And in the process, I said a bunch of things I shouldn't have. You are my best friend in all of time and space, and I don't want to ruin what we have. I know you're not like that. You're not that kind of bloke. You're like a sort of... outer space Gandalf or something."

That got a smile out of him.

"So, what I'm trying to say is that I'm sorry I came onto you last night, I'm sorry I drank so much and was an ordeal for you, because that wasn't fair to you, and... well, now I'm just rambling, going all stream of thought and you have never been so quiet."

He nodded. "Yes, well, I appreciate you saying all that. For the record, I wasn't angry at having to wait on you last night, nor having to drag you back to the TARDIS. I'm glad you got to achieve that feeling, although, I'm sure there are other ways to achieve it," he said with a grin.

She blushed. "Yeah, I know. Just got carried away." She patted her stomach. "Seem to be doing that a lot lately."

The Doctor smiled. "Yeah, that seems to happen to some people on the TARDIS..."

Donna's eyes widened. "You wha?"

"Well, occasionally, I've noticed the odd companion get a tad... shall we say... 'podgy'...?"

"You mean your previous companions got fat as well?!"

"Not all of them. Just a few here and there. I remember Dodo indulging a bit more frequently over time... Zoe -- poor girl couldn't fit into her catsuit for a while there. And Liz -- granted, we didn't do much traveling together, but I think that's one of the reasons she left..."

"You're kidding me!"

Donna put a finger to his lips. "Time out! You're telling me I'm not the first to gain weight on the TARDIS?!"

The Doctor shrugged helplessly. "It's not my fault! I don't do anything to make it happen! The TARDIS just seems to... do that sometimes."

All of Donna's concerns and suspicions became confirmed at once. "The TARDIS fattens your companions up?!"

"Doesn't happen all the time. Never happened with Rose or Martha. Sarah Jane -- we traveled together for ages -- she ballooned a bit, but she decided to get back in shape afterwards..."

Donna swallowed. "Did they... get as big as me?"

The Doctor shrugged again. "Never really paid attention. Not the sort of thing I'd notice."

"So that's a 'no, they didn't'." Donna ran her hands through her hair. "It's all beginning to make sense now... But why me?!"

"Well, the TARDIS likes you. Maybe it's... how she shows affection?"

Donna thought about that. All those times the TARDIS straight up gave her food, almost force feeding her. All the times they landed in relaxing places so she didn't have to run too much and burn too many calories.

"Right then," she said at last, making up her mind. "Excuse me. I need to have a word with your ship."
